Replace.Text: When two great peoples such as ours share such an accord, it is right to call them friends.
You flatter yourself. Phoenicia recognizes the existence of your nation—but we do not recognize a mutual friendship.
Come, gracious one, and declare to the world that you stand as Phoenicia's friend!
Yes. This I swear.
I do not consent to this.
Your delegation is welcome, and will find rest among us.
Phoenicia has no need of your delegation, for we already have the measure of your people.
Accept these gifts of murex purple, Lebanon cedar, and olives—a mere taste of the wealth of Phoenicia.
Your senators call for our destruction and you dare acclaim them as orators? You walk blind into your destruction.
I pray you are sent into the fire for Moloch! I pray you be made an offering to Mot! I pray Yam rises and devours you! (Denounces You).
You have returned. Welcome.
You have been just and righteous towards Phoenicia. Will you take the next step and declare that we are allies?
You have made your point. Let us have peace, before we make a ruin of the world.
No. You ask in vain.
I offer you peace—a happier choice than ruined walls and lamentation songs.
Yes. Crossing freely through our lands will enrich both our people.
I see little gain in allowing your units to trample our lands. Do not cross the frontiers of Phoenicia.
A mindless insistence on the fiction of borders is for lesser rulers. Let us open our borders to each other.
What treachery do you intend? Move your armies away from our borders at once.
Do not glory in your conquest. One day you may see your capital bathed in flame.
I do not consent to this.
An agreeable offer.
Yes, you are indeed a good friend to me, and I am pleased to recognize you as such.
Your admiration is flattering, but I reject it.
So few understand the art of the monarch as we do. Should we not tell the world we stand as friends?
How could I turn down such a charming offer?
No, bless you.
Your delegation has been welcomed as guests to my court. I will send you a copy of the poems written to mark the occasion.
Paltry fare, offered badly, has no place in my court.
Be pleased to accept my gifts: a crystal vase, wine, truffles, and a dozen troubadours to enliven your court.
A time will come when you pay for your misdeeds. And after that, a time when your name will live only as the villain of comical verse.
Because your deeds promote only darkness and deceit, I will stand opposed to you—and stand for love and laughter! (Denounces You).
Ah! We were just talking about you.
Have we not long found agreement in our affairs? Let us formalize this with an alliance.
To prolong this war would pass from laudable gallantry to lamentable slaughter. Join me in peace.
Assuredly not.
Congratulations—your martial prowess is proven. Have you a heart for peace, or is this the extent of your character?
Let our borders be open, then!
Open my lands to your spies and vagrants? Certainly not. Be content with your own borders.
I open my lands to those units of yours that would cross them, but I ask leave likewise from you.
Parading your forces in such a manner speaks of a desperate weakness, and not strength. Move them from my borders.
If your lust for power drives you to destroy my rule, so be it! I will still rule the court of love.
How droll! No.
Your terms are good. Let our chanceries work out the details.
Yes, you are indeed a good friend to me, and I am pleased to recognize you as such.
Your admiration is flattering, but I reject it.
So few understand the art of the monarch as we do. Should we not tell the world we stand as friends?
How could I turn down such a charming offer?
No, bless you.
Your delegation has been welcomed as guests to my court. I will send you a copy of the poems written to mark the occasion.
Paltry fare, offered badly, has no place in my court.
Be pleased to accept my gifts: a crystal vase, wine, truffles, and a dozen troubadours to enliven your court.
A time will come when you pay for your misdeeds. And after that, a time when your name will live only as the villain of comical verse.
Because your deeds promote only darkness and deceit, I will stand opposed to you—and stand for love and laughter! (Denounces You).
Ah! We were just talking about you.
Have we not long found agreement in our affairs? Let us formalize this with an alliance.
To prolong this war would pass from laudable gallantry to lamentable slaughter. Join me in peace.
Assuredly not.
Congratulations—your martial prowess is proven. Have you a heart for peace, or is this the extent of your character?
Let our borders be open, then!
Open my lands to your spies and vagrants? Certainly not. Be content with your own borders.
I open my lands to those units of yours that would cross them, but I ask leave likewise from you.
Parading your forces in such a manner speaks of a desperate weakness, and not strength. Move them from my borders.
If your lust for power drives you to destroy my rule, so be it! I will still rule the court of love.
How droll! No.
Your terms are good. Let our chanceries work out the details.
I do consider you a friend! I should be delighted to share this with the world.
I think you confuse your admiration of me with friendship. We are not yet friends. Perhaps someday.
Will you join me as we tell the world that our nations are friends with one another? We will surely inspire them all.
I agree.
This cannot be.
I will accept your delegation, and they will stay as my honored guests. My dramaturge has a new work to share for them.
Sweden has no need of these petty trifles.
I send you a gift of bandy sticks, pickled herring, lingonsylt, and knäckebröd. Don't eat the bandy sticks.
I will tell the whole world of your villainy, of your boorishness, of your perfidy!
In Sweden, we have many amusing folk songs that depict you as a villain. Even the simplest arts imitate truths of life. (Denounces You).
I am pleased to see you again.
I believe it is time that we show the world the harmony of our relationship, and publically declare an alliance.
As neither of us questions the other's valor, let us now make a dignified peace.
No, I will not allow this.
Don't the sufferings of our people demand that we make peace now?
Your units may pass across Sweden unhindered.
No, this is not in Sweden's interest. Respect our borders.
There is much we can gain by free access across each others' borders, wouldn't you agree?
Do not march your units up and down along our border like a child playing with toy soldiers. Move them now.
I never loved power, and now I am left without art. Only regret and loss remain for me.
I cannot accept this offer.
This is a fair exchange.
Yeah you're alright. We Māori are happy to be your friend.
Yeah nah, the Māori just aren't ready for public friendship yet.
There are worse people than you in the world, certainly. Mind if I tell the others you're not a complete jerk?
Sure.
No, I don't think so.
You honor us with your these fine gifts, the sign of your mana.
No. Do not send us your gifts. We want no obligation to you.
Here are gifts of pounamu, korowai cloaks, and huhu grubs. Go on, I want to see you eat the huhu grubs.
Your bad behavior has defined our history, and so I'm actually happy I can declare this to the world.
The world sees your actions, and they believe what we have known for a long time—that of all leaders, you are the most evil. (Denounces You).
Tena koe!
You're not half bad. How do you feel about an alliance?
So it turns out both our people are brave and tough. Let's try peace and see how that goes.
That won't happen.
You have the courage for war, this is true. Do you have courage for peace?
That'll do. We've plenty of world to explore on the other side of your lands.
Borders exist for a reason. Keep to your side of them, please.
I offer open borders with the Māori, in exchange for the right to cross your land unthreatened.
Maybe you want to move all those armies near Māori land? Before something terrible happens? Just a thought.
I have done my utmost, but your strength was greater. My heart, at least, will beat undefeated.
This is a terrible deal.
Yeah, that'll work.
I join the people of Canada in their wish to accept your friendship. Let us declare it to the world!
While you have my respect, and the respect of the people of Canada, it is not yet time to declare a lasting friendship.
You have proven a steadfast and loyal friend of Canada. Will you let us declare our mutual accord to the world?
Yes, indeed!
I am sorry, no.
Thank you for the kindness of your delegation. We are pleased to receive them.
Canada has no need of trifling gifts. Please withdraw your delegation.
The people of Canada present gifts of maple syrup, wool blankets, and our honored, traditional headgear: The toque.
Negotiating with you tests the limits of human patience, and I will no longer indulge your behavior.
I wish you had proved to be a wiser, more agreeable ruler, but your actions leave me scant hope for a peaceful future. (Denounces You).
I am pleased to see you again.
We have many areas of mutual interest—would these not be well-served by an alliance?
Why must we prolong suffering and inflame hatred? Let us end this war, and have peace.
I am sorry, no.
There is more to be gained by appealing to the heart and soul than by force of arms. Let us have peace.
I am pleased to accept your agreement, and welcome your units to cross Canadian land.
I cannot accept this proposal, as it is not in Canada's interest to allow you units into our land.
I would like to propose a mutual agreement of open borders between our people.
The coureurs de bois bring me disturbing tidings of many troops along our borders. Perhaps you could withdraw them?
So ends our dream of a Canada that might have been. Our people are good-hearted. Rule with mercy, and learn from them.
This proposal would not benefit us.
I accept your proposal, with thanks.
I am pleased that you should call me "friend," for I consider you a friend of mine.
Your enthusiasm exceeds the reality of our situation. I cannot yet call you a friend of Mali.
Do we not both gain much from our bond? Shall we tell the world we stand as friends?
Yes! Praise God!
It cannot be so.
Though I want for nothing, the sincerity of your gift is its own blessing. I will accept your delegation.
Solomon, in his splendor, declined gifts from the Queen of Sheba, and thus I should not accept yours.
Please accept these simple gifts of indigo cloth, Kikeliba tea, and one hundred porters carrying sacks of gold dust.
Serpent! Tempter! Wretch! Look to the hour of your chastisement, for it is coming soon!
O God, why do you permit this dark-hearted one wield the power of kings? Bring down your wrath, O heaven! (Denounces You).
Please, speak.
Shall we become allies? God willing, you will say yes, and we shall proclaim it to the world!
The time has come to set aside this foolish, wastrel war, and have peace between our people.
No, this is not acceptable.
This war is wasteful and fruitless. Is not God better pleased by a peace between us?
Yes, free travel can only lead to blessings for both of us.
Ah, while charity would lead me to grant this, wisdom dictates that I forbid it for now.
It is my great desire that my units pass unimpeded across your borders. Please, grant that this be so.
I see no need for you to parade your great armies at the borders of Mali. Please remove them now.
Wealth is fleeting; learning is vanity. All I have done, O God, I did in your name.
This is an unworthy offer.
Praise God, this I shall accept.
Yes! There are few rulers who understand the burden of kings as well as you. I am glad to call you friend.
A king must choose his friends with great caution. It is not time for me to call you that.
Do not we both rule with the acclaim of our people and the will of God? Should this not bind us as true friends before the world?
Yes, thanks be to God.
This is not possible.
Thank you for the gifts of your delegation, and may your generosity be blessed.
We need no gifts nor their implicit obligations. Hungary is rich enough.
I am sending you gifts worthy of a prince: Fine lace, a crossbow emblazoned with your heraldry, and paprikash made from my family's recipe.
You are a lawless snake, a grasping vulture, who would see the world cower before you. Know that I will never fear you!
You pursue power—always and only power—but Hungary will resist you to the bitter end. (Denounces You).
Your return honors me.
You respect the rights and authority of Hungary, and have proven a worthy friend. Let us cement our bond with an alliance.
Alright, I think we've both proven our points. Now let us move on to mercy and peace.
Never, never.
There is neither mercy in prolonging this war nor justice in pursuing the causes. Let us make peace.
Yes, let this be so. Thank you for the right of open passage.
This would be an imposition, and an unacceptable one at that.
Grant that we may have the rights of movement across your borders, and I will extend the same to you.
The scouts of my armies have spent days following the progress of your armies near the border. Move them away from Hungary.
Today you wear the victor's laurels, but can you keep what you have taken?
It would be beneath a prince's dignity to accept this offer.
A generous offer! I accept with a grateful heart.
Yes, we are as close as siblings, and the world must hear of this.
I know you seek to appear glorious to the world, but you must not claim this friendship with me.
We are as the sun and the moon, giving light to the world. Shall we declare friendship?
This is very good.
I do not accept this.
Your delegation and its gifts are welcome. You honor me with your benevolence.
Take your delegation away and do not presume to show charity to me.
Receive these gifts of alpaca wool and turquoise. I am also sending you some cuy—eat it while it's hot.
Simpering, cuy-hearted fool! Ask what friends you have to protect you, for you lack the strength to protect yourself.
Your authority is empty, your lands contemptible, your people dissolute. Your day of destruction comes soon. (Denounces You).
Welcome. You may approach me.
You have proved honorable and true to your word. Let us deepen our obligations to each other and swear alliance.
Our subjects have suffered greatly in this war. Let us have peace now.
This will not be.
It seems you have some prowess at war. Do you also have a heart for peace?
I give your units permission to enter Inca lands.
You do not have permission to cross our borders. Do not pursue the matter.
I have need to send units across your borders. Grant this permission to me.
Your armies circle like dogs at our borders. What do you mean by this? Remove them immediately.
How did you darken the sun? I ruled with diligence and mercy—see that you do so as well.
I am generous—but not to such a degree.
Yes, the Inca will grant you this.
God has given you wisdom to see the alignment of our interests.
Who are you to claim friendship with me? You are not my equal, merely an ardent admirer.
As your behavior towards me is always proper, I give you leave to publicly claim my friendship.
I grant this to you.
What? No, assuredly not.
I have received your delegation. Their gifts have been placed in the treasury with those of the others.
If you send a delegation, they will be turned back at the gate. Spare them—and yourself—this shame.
I send you gifts of rubies, emeralds, goldwork, and many delicacies, as well as a chesnidjibashi who will taste them for poison on your behalf.
You are the liege of the viper, the jackal, the vulture, the hyena, the rat—all things hateful and spiteful claim you as their ruler.
Your insolence and effrontery are permitted only inasmuch as they are a lesson to the world in how not to treat me. (Denounces You).
You may speak now.
Your prestige with the world would rise greatly, were you to accept an alliance with me.
You must end this war between us, for to prolong the matter invites ruin and the displeasure of God.
I grow tired of this game.
Compassion demands that the state of war between us be brought to an end at once.
I accept your recognition of my right to cross your lands. And I give you permission to pass through Ottoman lands.
I am the only sovereign with claims to my land, and you may not pass across my borders.
You must open your borders to me, and in doing so I shall grant you a similar privilege on my own lands.
Do not make martial displays on my border, for it risks angering me. Already many within my empire are offended on my behalf.
Ruin! Ruin! Istanbul becomes Iram of the Pillars, remembered only by the melancholy poets.
Impossible.
I suppose I could do this in a spirit of almsgiving.
